doc.previous: Wolters was given the additional task in 1941 of setting up a special section of the government publishing house which specialized in works of architecture.[15] Wolters wrote several books on the Third Reich's architectural works during the war years. He rejected the notion that Nazi architecture was an imitation of classical models:[16] "Those who speak of neo-classicism have not understood the spirit of our buildings."[17]
doc.after: In February 1942, following the death of Fritz Todt, Hitler appointed Speer as Minister of Armaments and War Production.[18] Wolters followed Speer to his new ministry, becoming head of the Department of Culture, Media, and Propaganda of the Organization Todt.[6] Wolters continued his Chronik in the new position.[19]
